39057451.review:
88/100 - worth the grind.

Clannad is a fantastic visual novel with a case of poor pacing for a lot of the routes (which to get the true ending you need to do every single one).  The game focuses on life and romantic relationships with 0 erotic content.   It is an "All ages" visual novel which is perfectly fine by me.

The game follows a day format which works fine for the primary story but for some of the branches you can tell that they did their best to fill in the days where not much happened.  For me, this turned into a feeling of disinterest where I needed to put the game down for a bit and come back to get reinvested.

Don't misunderstand,  I love the game and recommend it to anyone who takes visual novels or reading seriously. However, it is a long game.   I believe the game is reported to have over 1.3 million English words in the script.  Which put it at 30% more than the 7 Harry Potter books combined and more than the Bible.

What I am getting at is that it isn't 2 hours pick up and put down thing.  If you buy it you're getting your monies worth for sure but if you hate reading or are expecting any sort of erotic material you will be much sad.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Personally,  while this is a high tier visual novel to me.  It doesn't feel top tier and although I played through this prior to the anime with no information going in... Unlike games such as Fate, I felt that the extras from the visual novel didn't expand on the story as much as it  could have.   The anime brings a lot of life and expression to a very solid story in a much more digestible format. Since the story focuses primarily on the people and not on some larger over-arching plot... expression and personality are so very important.

This is coming from a person that almost always believes in source material over adaption because most of the time something is lost in the middle. As well as someone who has enjoyed visual novels for many years when even completely clean VNs were seen as smutty due to some of the related material in the genre.

Something else worth talking about is the art style is not for everyone.  This is a visual novel from early 2004 and it looks like it was made in the late 90s.  Characters tend to look a bit off and while not an issue for me as suspending disbelief is a part of any partaking in fiction.  I have had many people comment to me asking about "What is up with the art". 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

There is also a dark undertone to a lot of the story in the visual novel specifically with the protagonist that maybe requires some knowledge in psychology to really feel out but... without spoiling anything I just don't feel like the visual novel version of the protag is a good person really and on deeper reflection many of the plot points that are billed to you as positive have some very uncomfortable undertones when looked at closely.  Not that there is anything wrong with creating a character that is complex but it sort of betrays the narrative a lot of times in the context of the plot itself.  However, that is a nitpick about a character and not to be confused with the quality of the product.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Overall this is a very solid although, sometimes slow visual novel.
Plan to read this over a longer period of time as it averages out to around 80 hours or more depending on reading speed to get everything out of it.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Make up your own mind.
DanielJMWaters

39425717.review:
CLANNAD.

My first VN I've ever played AND finished, and by golly, do I have some words for this game.

Now, I got this game for free thanks to my boyfriend. However, you're gonna notice how I have over 70 hours in this game. And you're going to average out to around the same if you're aiming for all route/achievements/scenarios like I did. So if you can't spare 3-4 days worth of your tears on this beautiful game, stop reading this now, back out of this game, and go find another VN that'll satisfy your short attention span, because this game clearly isn't worth your 50$. If you're still here, congratulations. I'm going to praise this game like no tomorrow.

As a forewarning, I used a guide for this entire game to ensure good endings for all routes, and I read fast: even that didn't save me in the sense that I spent the equivalent of 3 consecutive, non-stop days to getting all achievements in this game. I even skipped a lot of the cutscenes after finishing my first route and that wasn't enough to spare me from the neverending story this game offers. However, I did not achieve 100% CG mode or 100% Dangopedia, and I probably won't be bothered to go back to do them, so I'm much more satisfied with a 77 hour run. Without further ado, let's go on to the game.

THIS IS A VERY STORY DRIVEN GAME. This isn't your average VN by any means. You take control of Tomoya Okazaki, a deliquent 3rd year, who is on his last year of primary school and is about ready to graduate high school with his lousy but very lovable and comedic deliquent friend, Youhine Sunohara. One day, while you're walking late to school as usual one April morning, you meet a girl you've never seen before named Nagisa Furukawa at the bottom of a hill that directly leads to the high school, seemingly onlooking the hill like a ferocious, complicated challenge. She seems shy, anxious, and naive, but despite his rather harsh personality, Tomoya reluctantly agrees to walk up the hill with her to the high school. Thus begin their friendship: Nagisa wants to rebuild a drama club that disbanded last year, and it's literally up to you if you decide to help her rebuild the club or let her do it alone. If you do decide to help her, you must face hardships that is forming a club, holding meetings, finding members, advertising the club itself, and even performing a play (based on a fairytale) at the school's Founder Festival. But along the way, you make countless memories with both Nagisa and Sunohara, and meet many new people, both in and outside of school, who become your friends, and will do anything to help Nagisa's dream of revitalizing the drama club come true. THAT IS THE BASE, SPOILER-FREE STORYLINE, IT CAN AND WILL CHANGE BASED ON THE GIRL YOU DECIDE TO ROMANCE.

The amount of story this game has is enough to keep you up at night- this game has kept me up multiple nights until 6 am EST just to finish a single route. This game has more routes than you can think of. And you have to literally work for all of them. If you're going in blind your first try like I did, chances are you may not even meet half the girls you can "romance" much like I did until I searched up a guide. I got the bad ending my first run through, so don't feel bad if you did as well. I didn't use a guide, so I went with my wits and made choices based on what /I/ would do. However, upon getting the bad ending, I was at loss about what I did wrong, so I used a guide for the rest of the game. That did not deter my enjoyment for this game, though!

Speaking of choices, this game is heavy on those. Your choices heavily depend on what route the game takes you. So, essentially, one single choice can lead you astray from Nagisa's path and put you in Kyou's/Ryou's path. It's literally that simple. Think of it as Mass Effect: your choices literally matter on the path that you take. Some choices are more important than others: one will directly affect what route you go on, others don't make as much of a difference in any given route. That's what makes this game have replay value if you're an achievement whore like me, or if you just like very story-drive game. It's a beautiful game that knew where to put its money. Gorgeous music, ungodly speechless artwork, and storylines to haunt you for days and keep you up at night, this game is clearly a must-have for VN fanatics and collectors everywhere. You'll feel for every character and the music captivates each scene flawlessly. I related with Nagisa and Kyou the most while I fell in love with Kappei, Tomoyo, and Tomoya's father. Kyou's theme is the best music in the game hands down in my opinion.

However, with every good game, it also has its many flaws: this game is no different. I won't go over every single detail I'd like to nitpick at, I'll keep it pretty minimal. Remember when I mentioned replay value earlier? Well, this game forces replay on your ass if you want the true ending, which is why you'll see some people like myself have ridiculous hours tagged into the game. If you want the true end, you're going to have to play the game's main storyline a total of 8 times, (13 if you decide to do every route) and get 8 lights by the end of it. After you get 8 lights from the routes + doing Fuko and Nagisa routes (they are required as they are canon), After Story will be unlocked. You then have to play After Story THREE (3) TIMES to get the true ending. In total, this can average out anywhere from 50-100 hours, if you decide to read all the dialouge. Of course, you can argue that VisualKey did this to pad out the story as much as possible, and to make you work for such an ending, but it kinda drags that I have to skip 90% of the route just to get a light orb to get the true ending. In the end, Nagisa's and Fuko's routes are the only two that matter for After Story's storyline, but the other routes have to be played solely for orb collecting.

Ryou's route also rubbed me the wrong way. If you approach that route, you find out that Ryou has shyness and troubles socializing. While I understand the irony of "she's the class president but she has troubles talking", it rubs off more as a overbearing cliche after a while than simple character development. While Ryou did have her good moments, more notably towards the very end of her route, her shyness and social issues became more of a simple annoyance than cute or adorable. It made it look like while they were giving light to the situation of those who suffer it, it only make it worse by making it look like they tried to glorify or beautify girls who suffer anxiety and diffiiculties in socializing. This is coming from a woman who struggles with both general and social anxiety. Social anxiety is not cute. No one is going to save you 24/7. I felt like her whole gimmick of being overbearingly shy and socially awkward was to make Kyou, Ryou's slightly older twin sister, look like the strong, protective sister when even that got old and rather frustrating real quick to deal with. It was cliche and typical, and I felt like they could've made Ryou's route more bearable and understandable for those who don't suffer immense shyness or social issues, and gave Kyou more of an excuse to protect her sister other than the fact that she can't handle the slightest of situations that aren't part of her comfort zone. In a real world setting, Kyou would be doing far more harm than good for Ryou. But this is just a video game, right? I know I seem triggered by something annoyingly meant as entertainment, but it bugged me and made that route very uncomfortable and very unenjoyable for me to sit through. I just wish they approached the socially anxious minority more realistically.

But with that out of the way, now it's time for my final ratings!

[b][u] Music: [/u][/b] 9.5/10
[b][u] Storyline: [/u][/b] 9.9/10
[b][u] Gameplay: [/u][/b] VN/10
[b][u] How is the Price??[/u][/b] Somewhat fair. I'd wait for a sale on this game, personally. Sorry.

39501406.review:
[h1] Clannad是一部非常非常非常不错的作品，也是我最喜欢的galgame [/h1]


人会长大三次。
+第一次是在发现自己不是世界中心的时候。
+第二次是在发现即使再怎么努力，终究还是有些事，令人无能为力的时候。
+第三次是在，明知道有些事可能会无能为力，但终究还是会尽力争取的时候。

故事的开始是那么的美好，日常，日常，继续日常，直到进入了AS，汐出生，渚去世，之后冈崎和古河一家的痛苦与悲伤

身为人父，方知其苦。
朋也终于理解了他的父亲。
这一次——他也想做好一个父亲的角色。

在经历了几百个小时，无数次刷过剧情之后，终于集齐13个光玉，与渚擦肩而过的樱花路下，主角撕心裂肺的那句：

NAGISA！！！！！！！！

完美通关之后真感觉像度过了一生一样，游戏虽然是二次元，却有着三次元的残酷，但正因为是二次元，又有着只有二次元才有的美好。不同的人，对里面不同的地方会有不同的感触，会被打动的地方不一样。每个人都能在Clannad里找到感动自己的点。

剧情真的很棒，人生也真是不容易

[h1] 请珍惜现在所有的一切，请坚持追逐自己的理想  [/h1]
